Machine worked flawlessly for first six months with little parts cleaning maintenance.  Then, after about 6-8 months, the suction died.  I took it apart, cleaning and looking for obstructions, finding none.  With recovery tank removed, the suction is powerful coming directly from vacuum engine port.  Once recovery tank was replaced, all gaskets inspected, nozzle cleaned and lid on securely, there was still scant suction.  This is a design problem that needs to be fixed.  Thank goodness I bought from COSTCO with the always return policy with a full refund.  I'll try a different model or manufacturer for this as next step. Bottom line: If you can get from COSTCO and replace as necessary not minding the hassle factor, it's a good choice.  If purchased anywhere else, try another model or manufacturer

This stuff works really well and it's easy to use. I had to use the entire box of these to seal up all of the holes in this house, it dries a fairly bright white and is easily painted over.

All you need to get started is a caulk gun and its really simple after that. Just cut the tip off to the required length, further down for a larger bead, and higher up for a thinner bead. It works really well for sealing small holes, and also very large holes. It takes probably about a 30 minutes to an hour to fully dry if you're sealing a large hole with it, however smaller holes will dry within minutes. Be careful not to get it on your hands as it is a pain to get off.

I entered a number of local "do-it-yourself" stores (that shall go unnamed) looking for a strong glue/adhesive to bond some laminate hardwood flooring planks to concrete slab that had come unglued after months of wear and tear. Up and down the aisles I went in search for the strongest, and cheapest, glue on the market. And then I saw it, hiding behind the "lush" collection of paint supplies: Gorilla Glue. It immediately caught my attention as it peered out from behind the confines of paint trays and rollers. I asked the attending sales associate about this product, and he looked me in the eyes and said, "I have no idea, but it sounds cool!" That was all all needed to hear. I arrived back at my house twenty-five minutes later curious and ready to make it happen. I followed the instructions on the back of the bottle and went to work. For someone not versed in the world of glues and looking for a simple, cheap way to fix a problem, I was easily impressed with Gorilla Glue's ability to get the job done. I highly recommend it to the working folks who are too busy to get to those projects around the house! Trust the gorilla...

I did not buy 2-P10 adhesive from/through Amazon.  CA glues of any viscosity do not work well with wood as a means of making solid permanent joints.  Oh, it sets up in a few seconds and faster when an accelerator is used, but the bond/joint is easily broken especially when a twisting or torsioning force is applied to the joint, much easier than a true wood glue joint. 2-P10 exhibits all the positive aspects of any CA glue - and the negatives, too.

2-P10 is as good as any other CA glue for very small projects such as Popsicle stick crafts, and high gloss finishes for pens and other small turnings, and is more expensive than most brands.  There are dedicated wood glues that set up quickly and don't require accelerators or debonders (nail polish remover) or other additional chemicals to work.

Homeowner remodeling.  Bought four of these pump jack systems - set three up and needed two more braces.

I read the reviews before deciding to purchase and saw most of the not-so-good marks related to the 30" span the brace will provide.  I have no issue with this span.

Concerning the brace, it works as advertised.  However, here are some of the issues I encountered:
- the metal plates that surround the double 2x4 don't fit exactly.  They are about 1/8 not wide enough.  Luckily the enclosed carriage bolt was long enough to allow me to attach them.
- had to use a wire brush wheel on the carriage bolt to get the paint off of them.  Would like to see stainless steel provided by the manufacturer and not painted steel.  I will replace mine with SS soon.  Luckily, I have a bench grinder/wheel and removing the paint wasn't difficult.
- not fond of the 32" span.  My old house (100+ years) was buitl with 24" centers (I didn't know they did that yars ago until I tore my house apart).  This was easily resolved by attaching an old 1/4 (7/8 thick) to the 2x4's and then attaching the brace to this, putting a 2x4 block behind the brace for additional screw support.
- not fond of having a wing nut to hold the carriage bolt.  Doesn't seem like it would be substantial enough, but it is.  I'll replace it with a regular hex nut (with washer and star lock washer) when I change the carriage bolt to stainless.
- I understand why the supports that attach to the house are vertical, but that didn't do me much good since I wasn't attaching directly to studs.  Easy to work around, however.

My double 2x4 columns are 24' long - I have the top brace 2" down from the top because I need to pump the system to the top.  I should have went with 30' columns, but I didn't know this until the 1st column was put into place.  If you run columns this long, plan for two braces unless you feel comfortable with swaying.  I am able to park the system above the lower brace (which are positoned about 8' from the ground) and reach the scaffold via a deck that's next to my work area.

NO CORNER BRACES EXIST!  I searched high and low and cannot find a corner brace - one that will allow me to walk around a corner via a scaffold resting on top of another scaffold.  Simple to design, however, and I will have mine created by a fabrication shop this winter before I set up to put vinyl siding on my house.

Overall, the braces work as advertised and I'd buy them again.

I have gone through quite a few tubes for sealing exterior siding and caulking around window and door trim after replacing a lot of windows and 3 exterior doors.

It goes on easily and fills cracks well because is not too "stiff".  However, when the pressure is released, the caulk continues to slowly keep coming out. With a narrow bead, about 3/32", it can ooze out up to eight inches.  When I stop to reposition the caulk gun, it oozes enough that I have to wipe off the spout because there is too much to caulk accumulated on it to make a clean transition when resuming caulking.

I suspect the continued oozing is a packaging problem such that the pressure is not fully relieved when the caulk gun ram mechanism is completely released.  This makes the job much messier than it should.

I have used both white and almond and they behave the same way.  It sets up fairly quickly, like latex paint, but does remain flexible.

If you have small defects, such as a depression around a nail head, you can just get some caulk on your finger and smear it over the defect.  It seals it quite well and while leaving a slight depression, it seals much better than filler.

It does store well.  I just put an electrical wire nut over the spout and screw it on.

If you have gaps greater than 1/8", use a backing filler and plan on making a couple of passes with several hours between them.  It is not stiff enough to fill larger gaps.  Don't expect to be able to fill larger gaps so that they are flush - expect a slight depression at the gap.

I read the directions very carefully to make sure I didn't have issues with my gums- I've had severe sensitivity with all the whitening products I've tried so far whenever they touch my gums.
I was really happy with the mold-to-fit trays because I thought it would be easier to get the product right where I wanted it. The directions are very specific about how and where to apply the gel and I followed those exactly. When the tray pressed up against my teeth I'm guessing it pressed a little bit of the whitener up towards my gum-line. I experienced a small tingling sensation, but it wasn't something that bothered me to the point that I had to take the trays out.

Several hours after using the trays I ate dinner and my bottom gums felt like they were covered in canker sores. When I went to go brush my teeth I noticed a white film around my gum line - it wasn't leftover whitening, as I had made sure to scrub it all off. The white film was skin that was peeling off of my gums and leaving red raw patches.
I knew that the product said to try not to have your gums, tongue, or lips come into contact with the whitener, but I have never seen or had such a reaction to a whitener (I've tried several of Crest's and Listerine's whitening products).

On the plus side, my teeth are certainly a few shades whiter, so I have no doubt that they work! Unfortunately I won't be using them again.

I have a couple ideas of how to keep these things together.

Method 1.  Assemble all 4 of them and hold them vertically a foot or 2 above the ground and drop it.  Kaboom.  Then reverse the assembly end for end and repeat.  I find they are stuck together so tightly I can't get them apart.  I drop them on carpet or a door mat.  I'm afraid if I drop them on concrete, the ends could get bunged up.  If I have trouble with the curved parts of the gutter blower, I'll try a rubber mallet.

There are no more leaves to blow this year so I won't find out if they still blow apart until next year.

Method 2.  If method 1 fails, I will drill small holes where they overlap and put in some short sheet metal screws.

The picture is misleading. It shows a wheel that was machined. The actual wheel is made of sintered iron (looks like cast iron but it is easier to manufacture) and painted grey. It comes with all the pitfalls of chap casting, the major one being dimensional variability. There are more holes and smaller. The axle is bolt and nut - a plus because you can take it apart and add 10mm flat washers to stop the wheel moving from side to side. The bad part is that the wheel hole for the axle is not centered in the middle of the wheel and that the wheel hub side faces are not parallel to the wheel or to each other. So if you shim it with washers you will also have to clean the hub faces. Also the wheel hole for the axle is larger than the axle and even after shimming you will still get some side play. On the plus side is that the load is higher than the similar sized plastic wheels - the reason I bought them. You can also use more of them and mount them in a row to increase total load capacity while still maintaining maneuverability.
Unfortunately I could not find a better quality 2" fixed wheel with same load capacity even if I wanted to pay more.

Works as advertised, but there are a couple of shortcomings which are related and may not affect many people.
First, the span between the attachment points is 32" based on the assumption that they will be used with 16" stud spacing.  Since I was working high on the gable end of my house, I was attaching to the end roof truss which has 24" spacing between verticals.  My solution was to make an adapter out of a 2x4 which would fit between the brace and the house.
Second, the two mounting holes at each attachment point are 3" apart which means they can't both be used to attach to a horizontal 2x4 (ie: the adapter mentioned above).  I had to drill an aditional hole between the two existing holes on the brace so I could mount each side with two screws.
Since I pre-drilled the holes on the side of the house, I was able to mount them by myself with no problem.  I was able to hold the brace with one hand and insert the screw with the other while standing on a ladder.  They're not very heavy and since the attachment points swivel, the braces hang down while you're attaching them.  The only part of the job I found intimidating was handling the heavy poles (22 feet long in my case) while standing way up there.
It turned out that the 30" length was fine for my particular job, but they would certainly be more versatile if they were adjustable as mentioned by the other reviewers.

I purchased this Unibit to convert stainless beer kegs (purchased legally from a brewery, not stolen!) into a 15 gallon system for home brewing.  I had 8 holes I needed to drill out to ~1" to accommodate a 1/2" stainless female coupler. I did my best to keep the RPMs and feed rate down as to not work harden the stainless but despite my best efforts, the bit really struggled from 3/4" on. Part of the problem was maintaining the proper speed and feed with a hand drill but part of the problem was the burr formation on the bit as I used it. This started to happen around hole 5 and was somewhat surprising considering the hardness and price of this bit. Once the burrs formed, hence dulling and generating heat, my speed was no longer the problem due to the bit's inability to cut. The bit really struggled to make the 1" hole even when new but cut very easily through the stainless for smaller holes.  Perhaps a large drill press would do the trick but this was not practical for my use. If using this bit with stainless, watch your speed and feed and keep it cool as possible and stick to smaller holes. My bit will never cut another hole above 3/4" which is very disappointing considering the price I paid for it.

Following the recommendation of friends, we bought our very first electric toothbrush and have been very satisfied with the quality of the brushing.  We have, however, been sorely disappointed by the shelf-life of this product.  Had we known how short the product life is we would not have invested the money into a Sonicare product.  The set with two heads cost over $100.  Every 6 months we bought two replacement heads for over $20.  Three years into using the product, the battery died.  Upon calling the manufacturer, we were informed that the battery life should be 5 to 7 years; the warranty is only 2 years; the battery cannot be replaced and all we can do is throw away our still-functioning base and purchase a brand-new unit.  So beware, if you put your hard-earned dollars into this expensive product, it may only last three years and the manufacturer will not lift a finger to ensure you get the impression that this is just a buy and throw-away product.  Based on this experience we have no desire to invest in another Sonicare product.

We've used this glue for a variety of projects but to tell you the truth, it's really not one of our favorites.  We still use it occasionally but it's not our "go to" glue if you know what I mean.

If we're looking for a glue that will fill gaps we'll use.  Otherwise, we'll use something else.

What I Like:
-------------------------
 If you're not concerned about the appearance of the glue joint, it woks pretty well and it expands quite a bit so it can bridge gaps that other types of glues can't.  With other types of glue, if you use to much, it will skim over and only the surface will cure.  The glue that is under the skimmed over film won't usually set up.  This glue is moisture cured and doesn't have this problem.

What I Don't Like:
-------------------------
 It's very messy to work with and if you don't use gloves you're likely to get it on your fingers and it won't wash off with soap and water.
 If you get it anywhere other than the glue joint, post cure cleanup can be difficult.
 When it drys it expands a lot so there is often an extra clean up step once the glue is fully cured.  We often have to trim off any glue that expands out of the glue joint.
 As it cures and expands, the actual cured glue is quite porous.  By that I mean there will be several air bubbles in the cured glue.  At least we have found this to be the case with glue joints that aren't clamped tight during the curing process.

This Shop Vac is OK. The bigger, more expensive models are more powerful, but thats to be expected. Unfortunately, with Shop Vacs, you inevidibly, compromise power and performance when you go for the smaller models.

What I like about this vacuum:

1. Its lightweight-easy to carry around, especially when cleaning the car. I occasionally use it indoors as well.

2. I've used it a few times. If you clean the filter (or whatever it is that they tell you to empty and clean after each use) as recommended then the vacuum maintains its "full strength" power (as time goes by, it does lose strength when you're using it, but thats due to its small "holding" capacity-it can't stomach 16 lbs. of debris).

3. Price. Hey I paid ~$30, so I can't expect the performance of an industrial strength commercial cleaner or even my household canister that cost a few hundred bucks. But for the price, its a nice little tool for little jobs.

What I don't like about it:

1. It seems to blow a lot of dust around sometimes. But this may have more to do with how you hold it then the product itself. Because when I was cleaning my car, I'd notice sometimes an area that I had just cleaned would be dirty a few minutes later. And I think this was in part due to the how the vacuum was positioned because there is a part of it that vents out air which I think is responsible for blowing around debris and dirtying areas that had just been cleaned. So be mindful of how the vacuum is sitting or how you're holding it and you will be OK.

2. Not a lot of power. But like I said-for $30, I didn't buy this with unrealistic expectations. In fact, I was more impressed with what I got for the price, then anything.

3. Not place to store attachments-but hey, its a small vacuum made to be portable so I understand that there isn't room for that.

The church that I work for uses a fair amount of tape to put up signage at the school where we have our services. We need tape that affixes to mixed surfaces like brick walls and sandstone pillars. We've used this tape as well as Gorilla Tape , and I thought it might be useful to compare the two for potential purchases. Scotch's Heavy Duty duct tape is not nearly as heavy duty as Gorilla tape. It is thinner, less sticky, and not nearly a durable. In every way Gorilla tape comes out ahead in our applications. The only real advantage to Scotch's tape is that there is more of it per roll, and so it's about 20% cheaper than Gorilla tape. For some jobs, it probably doesn't matter which tape you use, so cheaper comes out ahead--but when you're trying to affix 30x40 foamboard signs to a brick wall, Gorilla tape is the clear winner.

Good:  Extremely strong bond.  Versatile over many types of surface applications. I glued the foam back together on a set of Oakley ski goggles two days ago.  Slope tested yesterday, it worked excellent.

Neutral:  Water activated.  You have to wet one side before applying it.  Limited shelf life-squeeze the air out each time, and next time I'd probably buy the 4oz version  unless you're using it constantly, because it goes a long way.

Bad: Foams a lot for a glue, and has a tendency to squeeze out from tiny cracks under compression.  This means you have to sit and monitor it and wipe off the foam as it comes out.  Silly boy you say, just use less glue....I did!  I had about twenty feet of a finished wood extender to put on our new kitchen cabinets to we could get the crown molding to fit.  By the end, I'd learned to put the glue on towards the back of the piece so it didn't squish out the front, and was using a very thin bead as well.

Bottom Line:  If I had two pieces of something to glue together and didn't worry about seeing some glue lines, I'd reach for this.  If I had something I planned on showing a finished face on, I'd use regular wood glue.  Depending on the strength I needed, I might use this, but I'd be very, very careful, otherwise you could wind up with a hard foamy mess on a finished surface.

First: I wanted to like this mouthwash.

My background: I brush and floss twice a day. I use the Rembrandt Deeply White fresh mint toothpaste and have been using it for the past few years with no problems (see my separate review for the Rembrandt winter mint toothpaste). I do love the Rembrandt toothpaste, it whitens and also does fight cavities, in fact I've only been to the dentist in the past few years due to routine cleaning, nothing more. Needless to say, I had high hopes for the mouthwash.

What I expected: I wanted my teeth to be whitened a bit more, mostly. The fresh breath wasn't a big deal, but would be nice. I also liked how there was fluoride in the mouthwash which was claimed to "strengthen enamel."

What happened: Yes, it works for whitening teeth. I noticed a difference within a few days. It was pretty impressive. However, due to how my teeth were already quite white, the difference wasn't anything spectacular. Just a nice shade whiter. Those with more yellow teeth, as is the case with most whitening products, are likely to see bigger results. The mouthwash also helps keep my teeth smooth. Freshening my breath? Ehh...it does but really not extremely so. In fact, I'd say that Listerine would probably do a better job if you just wanted fresh breath. It didn't make my teeth sensitive, either. But for strengthening enamel? On to that...

The ugly: After using the mouthwash for about a month and a half (used it twice a day, two capfuls as prescribed on the label for 1min. exactly), I had two bad experiences. First, when biting down on a somewhat tough bagel, my front tooth came down and chipped off a small piece of one of my bottom teeth. Second, while eating a strawberry, one of the seeds got stuck between my two front teeth where some cosmetic work had been done...it cracked one of my teeth! Not to the point where it caused pain, but there's a crack on the inside and it's now very difficult to floss between my two front teeth. It may be a result of using the Rembrandt toothpaste with the mouthwash and having too much peroxide overall, but the routine made my teeth very brittle. Moreover, Rembrandt does recommend using their own Deeply White toothpaste in tandem with this mouthwash. Funny enough, I was particularly keen to try this mouthwash as there is no alcohol in it, but it seems to have not mattered much. I have no idea how much peroxide is actually in this stuff, perhaps it's too much. So I ended up with a chipped tooth and a cracked tooth within a week of each other. That's when I stopped using the mouthwash. Keep in mind I've never chipped or cracked a tooth before this.

Afterthoughts: My teeth were already quite white to begin with and I just wanted to get them a bit nicer. Yes, the product made them a bit whiter. But it also made my teeth more brittle. I do bleach my teeth using professional grade gel, but that is once every half a year, and the last time I bleached was months ago, so I doubt that had much to do with it.

The price: isn't killer, just $5 a bottle here on amazon and free super saver shipping. Considering the damage it caused to my teeth, not exactly the deal of the century with how much dental work costs.

Conclusion: It does whiten teeth, and slightly freshen breath, but it doesn't strengthen enamel. If anything, it WEAKENS enamel. Again, it may just be my regimen. Because of the brittle teeth issue, however, I cannot recommend it.

 Any comments on how things could have been better are certainly welcome.

UPDATE: I contacted Rembrandt who promptly got back to me, and I spoke with a very kind representative over the phone about the issue. I thought about giving this 3 stars but that seemed harsh considering the low cost. I'm not sending this back because it's basically what I was looking for; simple, lightweight, disposable bag, inexpensive but functional. I've  used it exactly once and as other reviews note, it seems to have plenty of power despite other units having larger motors. It did the job. All that is positive. On the down side, the cord is pretty short--about 7-8 ft shorter than the Hoover we just retired so a coiled extension cord will be a permanent fixture. If you have large rooms, be prepared to plug/unplug frequently. Also the cord attaches to the sweeper head, not the top of handle which is awkward. You have to assemble and install the plastic handle which is why they mount the cord directly to the unit but when you pull it back toward you, the cord is frequently in the way. So, you have to do some cord control while you're working. It also has an annoying, high pitched whine/whistle. All vacuums are loud but this is very high pitched--maybe it's just a frequency that's bad for me(?). All that sounds bad but I really think it measures up to what I expected. Franky, we don't vacuum as often as we should, we have no pets, and we use a canister vac for a number of areas. It IS lightweight, so perhaps we will use it more often, being less cumbersome to carry from room to room.

As an owner of an "original" Sonicare (on my second actually) I am writing this review more from the perspective of whether the Elite is worth $[$$]+ as an "upgrade".
First, from an aesthetic and ergonomic point on view the Elite is a big step forward.  The handle is lighter and has a tapered shape with a rubber grip.  More importantly the brush head is smaller and is more of a diamond shape rather than the "original" rectangle.  The brush head "neck" is also angled to provide easier access to the back teeth and "flexes" both horizontally and vertically.
That being said, the Elite just does not seem as "powerful" as the original.  This is based not only on my subjective opinion of the "feel" while brushing but also on an objective "look" at the brush head while powered on.  Whereas the original has bristles that travel through a 90 degree arc, the Elite bristles barely travel at all.  Granted, this may be in part due to the smaller/shorter bristles.  Sonicare claims that the Elite is actually better from a functional point of view and I cannot say otherwise, so I will give them the benefit of the doubt.  (yes, i tested with the "beginner mode" turned off)
Also, after six weeks of usage, one of the magnets on the Elite brush head appears to have rusted significantly.  This was never a problem with the "original" Sonicare brush heads.  Whether this affects performance or not I cannot say.  As the brush head enters its third, fourth or fifth month of service I can only assume that the changes for decreased performance would increase.  Also, black "moldy" appearing deposits accumulate in the handle "well" which, also, never occured with the "original".  My guess here is that water is allowed to accumulate inside the brush head and handle well because of the flexible rubber housing (between the brush head "nut" and "neck") allows for the 360 degree "flex" I mentioned earlier-this housing is not sealed.  When I inquired, Sonicare denied(not having seen the unit) that what I was seeing was rust, and referred me to the cleaning instructions.  Take that for what it is worth...
I have found one interesting thing... While the "original" brush head will not fit the Elite handle, the Elite brush head WILL fit the "original" handle.  I detect no difference in the brushing experience using that combination.
My recommendations therefore are:
1) if you have never had a Sonicare then by all means buy the "Elite"... (but be wary of the rusting problem)
2) if you currently have an "original" that is on its last legs then buy an Elite (again be wary of the rust)
...

There are much more expensive commercial equivalent of this model that are more stoutly built but for non-commercial use, this unit works just fine.  Very simple and easy to use, vacuums as good as much more expensive models at a fraction of the cost.  Parts are easy to find and replace.  Only con is that the cord is a lot shorter than the commercial model.
